metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Daman Superstation, 2019)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Daman Superstation from January 1 to December 31, 2019. The site (100.372° E, 38.856° N) was located on a cropland (maize surface) in the Daman irrigation, which is near Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (AV-14TH;3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 40 m, towards north), wind speed and direction profile (windsonic; 3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 40 m, towards north), air pressure (CS100; 2 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 2.5 m, 8 m in west of tower), four-component radiometer (PIR&PSP; 12 m, towards south), two infrared temperature sensors (IRTC3; 12 m, towards south, vertically downward), photosynthetically active radiation (LI190SB; 12 m, towards south, vertically upward; another four photosynthetically active radiation, PQS-1; two above the plants (12 m) and two below the plants (0.3 m), towards south, each with one vertically downward and one vertically upward), soil heat flux (HFP01SC; 3 duplicates with G1 below the vegetation; G2 and G3 between plants, -0.06 m), a TCAV averaging soil thermocouple probe (TCAV; -0.02, -0.04 m), soil temperature profile (AV-10T; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m), soil moisture profile (CS616; -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_3 m, Ta_5 m, Ta_10 m, Ta_15 m, Ta_20 m, Ta_30 m, and Ta_40 m; RH_3 m, RH_5 m, RH_10 m, RH_15 m, RH_20 m, RH_30 m, and RH_40 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_3 m, Ws_5 m, Ws_10 m, Ws_15 m, Ws_20 m, Ws_30 m, and Ws_40 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_3 m, WD_5 m, WD_10 m, WD_15 m, WD_20 m, WD_30m, and WD_40 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) (μmol/ (s m-2)), average soil temperature (TCAV, ℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, below the vegetation; Gs_2, and Gs_3, between plants) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, and Ts_160 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, and Ms_160 cm) (%, volumetric water content), above the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_U_up and PAR_U_down) (μmol/ (s m-2)), and below the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_D_up and PAR_D_down) (μmol/ (s m-2)).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The meterological data during October 27 and November 13 and soil monitoring data during March 10 to 23 were wrong because the malfunction of datalogger. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2019-6-10 10:30. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (an observation system of meteorological elements gradient of Sidaoqiao superstation, 2018)

Quantification.Question: How many sensors are used to measure wind speed and at how many different heights are these measurements taken in a data collection method for meteorological factors in an agricultural area?

Interpretation.Question: What can the overlapping yet distinct height-based gradient observations of wind speed, temperature, and humidity tell us about the microclimatic variations within an agricultural field over the course of a year?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of multi-layered sensors at different heights (3m, 5m, 10m, 15m, 20m, 30m, 40m) for wind speed, temperature, and humidity allows for a detailed analysis of microclimatic variations. Observing these parameters at various levels helps infer vertical profiles of atmospheric conditions, which can reveal patterns such as temperature inversions, wind shear, and humidity stratification. These data can inform on how these parameters interact with the crop canopy, affecting processes like evapotranspiration and carbon exchange over time.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to data inaccuracies and gaps in atmospheric and soil measurements within comprehensive observation networks?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Factors that contribute to data inaccuracies and gaps include equipment malfunctions such as issues with data collectors, which can lead to missing data, as observed from October 27 to November 15, 2019, and incorrect data recording due to channel problems in soil data from March 10 to March 23. Other causes include duplicate records, data exceeding the physical or instrumental limits, and uncertainties marked in red within the dataset.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives in establishing a comprehensive observation network for surface processes in river basins, and how might this data facilitate advancements in meteorological and agricultural research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The comprehensive observation network aims to collect detailed meteorological and environmental data, crucial for understanding surface processes in river basins. This data can support advancements in meteorological modeling, climate research, and agricultural management by providing insights into local climate conditions, water resources, and crop growth patterns. The data can also aid in improving predictive models for weather and climate, optimizing irrigation practices, and enhancing decision-making in agriculture.
